As a scientist, inventor, & Tuskegee professor, Carver developed groundbreaking soil improvement techniques and invented hundreds of commercial and industrial products. His achievements broke down barriers for Black Alabamians and his impact can still be felt across this nation.

Today we recognized the one and only George Washington Carver. Born into slavery, Carver defied adversity to become the first African American to earn a Bachelor of Science degree. #BlackHistoryMonth https://t.co/RmKiGn78HF

In 2000, Mayor Perkins was elected the 1st Black mayor of Selma. Mayor Perkins was elected in 2020 and is once again serving as mayor! https://t.co/i2zJRgxWnb

Piercing together scraps of fabric and clothing, the original Gee‚Äôs Bend quilters‚Äîenslaved women from Gee‚Äôs Bend in the 19th century‚Äîcreated abstract designs that had never before been expressed on quilts. Their work was passed down over generations, gaining national recognition.

Loretta Pettway, Lucy Mingo, & Mary Lee Bendolph made their mark on history using the quilting lineage of Boykin, AL‚Äîbetter known as Gee‚Äôs Bend‚Äîto establish the Freedom Quilting Bee as a way to help African American women gain economic independence in 1966. #BlackHistoryMonth https://t.co/XXt32YNs0o
